24 Jan 2020, 18:02
Shelmo Porter
My mom was never part of them, though, because her mother (who is a strikingly Native American woman) did not stay with that man as her husband. She was married many times, and all seven of her daughters (mom included) are from different bloodlines.
24 Jan 2020, 18:02
Shelmo Porter
The Odettes are an interesting bunch. All I know of them from what little family lore I've gleaned is that they were fur trappers and traders on the far Northwest coast, between Washington and British Columbia. Then a few splintered off. Some went to the sea and became whalers, while some went to the mountains and became one with the local natives. Both lines eventually trickled down and came full circle in Washington, where they settled in logging towns along the Columbia river
24 Jan 2020, 18:01
Shelmo Porter
I'm a Wild Woman I guess.

I've traveled across the Atlantic for you, twice. You won't even do it once, despite your hypnotizing prose about doing everything for me and traveling to the end of the world. Even now that my entire world is crumbling and I feel like my heart is about to stop, you remind me of the few uncomfortable moments, decline to acknowledge all the time and effort I put into making up for it, project your hatred for Andrew on me and, worst of all, you won't see me. Not in person. Not even via video chat.

I'd still go to the end of all things for you, even now.
For you, Alec is almost too far. Never mind New Orleans or Europe.

Maybe your feelings for me are merely pity or misapplied loyalty, and I keep exasperating them with the way I try to save things and drown myself in the process, while all my other issues are pulling me down further.

This is no longer just about my own insecurities and obvious flaws (like jealousy and a lack of self-worth â€” I'd argue that this very message is an effort to fix the latter. I'm done being taken for granted!), it's about you refusing to even communicate anymore. You won't talk about our issues (or if you do, only in a distanced, accusatory fashion) or acknowledge that I'm trying my best to alleviate them. You won't tell me about your day. What keeps you awake. You know I'm here for you and that being there for you is one of the few things that gives me strength and calms me, yet you won't acknowledge me.

Given our past, we seem made for each other. Yet you make me out to be your worst enemy.
We are both abuse victims, yet you desperately try to turn me into an aggressor and an outright villain.

Maybe you've already moved on, figured out you were just stringing me along, and all of that radio silence is your way to get rid of me without having to be proactive.

In any case, I'm going to stay away from Facebook for the next few days, at least. Going to work on myself and my self-worth, since nobody else will ever have my back and I apparently just exhaust myself and others.

I'm not giving up. Not on you or myself, but I am on my own (again). The default state I'm so afraid of, yet 30 years should've made me gotten used to.

TLDR: I feel like you have no respect for me (and I'll lose all my respect for myself if I keep hounding you like a lovesick puppy). If you truly care for me, you'll be the one to make the next step towards me. I'm not going to be the only one to invest energy, only for you to rebuff me, ignore all the good and blame me for things in the past (things I've already acknowledged my fault for. Which is more anybody has ever done for me).

For later perusal, when you feel better yourself and aren't tired.

Here is how my father's letter feels:

It feels like being attacked for something I partly can't help and that, in large parts, the other party caused.

It feels like my own personality traits are being used against me and as if my parents' love is conditional on me playing after their fiddle.

I feel like people who should understand me don't understand me, at all. Like they won't let me be my own person but are hell-bent into molding me into their twisted mental image of what I should be.

They claim to know me, but all their attempts to understand me feel like self-congratulatory hogwash. Arrogant musings to deflect and project all blame. It feels like an attack, not like people trying to have my back.

I'm furious that part of the letter tries to scapegoat a person who has nothing to do with my anger and outright fury for them.

The whole letter reads like some sort of ultimatum and like it's trying to make me feel bad for being myself and for wanting some distance, peace and quiet.

Before I had left for Louisiana the first time this year, I felt at peace. Everything was in order and I liked my home the way it was.

Then I got back, only to find myself in front of the unknown. A large abyss. Unable to find my usual environment the way I had left it, I feel anxious, lost, confused and like a hurt animal. And now the people responsible for this fail to see the error of their ways, won't even consider an apology -- let alone make amends -- and instead blame me and an uninvolved third party, while they try to down play their actions.
10 Jan 2020, 01:51
Mark Bauermeister
And yea. I actually want to be in bed with you, having my arms around you. But the heater thing sounded more innocent and distanced, for what it's worth...

Mark Bauermeister
Anyhow

I need to disassociate for the rest of the night.

Gonna watch the Mandalorian, maybe record another YouTube gameplay video, then head to work early.

Hopefully this week I can get the ball rolling on a psychological evaluation for myself.

I looked into adult RAD, and these fit my personality:

- Excessive calling, texting, emailing, social media

- Keeping score of how long it takes someone to get back to you

- Acting too busy for others/ghosting
(I do this when I feel unappreciated or want to test people's reaction to my absence. I also have that deep urge to "punish" myself by becoming a hermit.)


- Trying to make others jealous

- Excessive attention on outer appearance
(I do this. Bitching about my looks and feeling insecure about myself, without really doing much about it short of the occasional fast)

- Needing reassurance to make decisions
(There are times I put off decisions for days or weeks because I feel I need to consult with a specific person first. That person could be a coworker, a friend, anybody I feel most apt to help me make a decision).

- Self-harm
(Mostly pushing my own body to the limits. I don't actively seek harm).

- Living in a fantasy world of books, movies, or video games

- Surface level therapy sessions

- Denial

- Failure to repair relationships

- A pattern of "holding it all together" and then experiencing emotional explosions
(I do this all the time. Often when seeking help early, involving others in a problem set or being more open about the hardship could've resolved the problem without "exploding".)

- Feeling shameful

7 Jan 2020, 01:20
Mark Bauermeister

Best to appeal to her in some fashion.

I dunno if telling her directly how you feel is the best course of action (that might get you into trouble if word gets out that you're "discouraging" your coworkers), but maybe make her understand and leave on her own accord.

It sucks, but the best way I can see to get out of it is to be a "bitch". If you were less supportive and she had to pull her own weight, she'd make the decision to leave sooner than later. It sucks. It truly does.

They finally put Trish in the bakery and she started her first day of training today.

Pros:
- she's very clean
- she's at least moderately organized
- she's engaging and likes observing how I complete tasks
- she listens to my (not always Paul approved) advice in regards to handling certain struggles we come across in the bakery.

Cons:
- she's very slow when completing even simple tasks
- she doesn't always shut up long enough to listen to what she needs to do
- she has a myriad of physical limitations (has all kinds of screws and cages etc in her spine and neck that prevent her from being able to bend over or lift even light items weighing 15-35 lbs. Also has some arthritis that makes piping frosting difficult for her and her writing pretty illegible).
- is a good observer, but very reluctant to attempt things herself.
- her memory is even worse than mine, and you know mine is wonky.

Shelmo Porter
Butter, garlic, little bit of salt. Throw it in the pan. Let it go til the butter is bubbly, then dump the meat in. Add cumin, cayenne pepper, black pepper, and cholula hot sauce. Allow meat to brown. Dump crushed tomatoes and about a quarter can's worth of water. Cover. Let simmer; sprinkle cheese on top and cover again. Remove when cheese is melted and serve with cornbread.

Mark Bauermeister
Just a "sneak peek" of my horrible "hatred" for you. ðŸ™„

- Towards the end of Star Wars, as I was wiping a tear off your face and gently touched your cheek, you grabbed my hand tightly, placed it over your chest and wouldn't let go for what felt like almost 20 minutes. I could feel your heartbeat and your tension.

- When I woke up a couple of times throughout the night and you had rolled over, straight into my arms.

- That day in Alexandria, when I woke up and your first words to me were "I feel much better today. Thank you for convincing me to come."

- Any time we lay in bed and face each other closely, I can see the warmth and lovingness in your eyes.

- When you talk about your problems or things you haven't told most other people, I feel wanted and needed.

- The way you worry about me even when I don't deserve being worried about.

- The way you and I both so swiftly picked up each other's peculiarities (such as you using that same sound I make whenever I can't explain something. Or me utilizing some of the same terms or phrasing you use). This isn't something found amongst strangers or even good friends. At this pace, it's only something found amongst lovers.

- In general, when one of us gets out of their own comfort zone to engage the other. That's what I'd consider a form of love, too. Soft "self-sacrifice".

- When we find enjoyment in each other's company and/or embrace their hobbies and quirks, that's love too.

- When one is angry with the other, but never for long. I can't hate you or be angry with you for longer than a short moment, exactly because I love you.

- When one can joke about the other's less-than-good traits or even find them sort of endearing. Like you did with my gluttony and, conversely, I do with your (road) rage.

- There are moments when I'm in utter distress and you have a strangely calming effect on me. I remember one day in November you were completely stressed from work but told me being around me (even though I'm a nervous wreck) calmed you. It's been the same way for me.

I don't have a "hate list".

I won't hurt you, no matter how much trust you put into me or how much you tell me.

You were alone and chose to rely on yourself.

I was alone and chose to cling to any passersby, no matter how fleeting.

Mark Bauermeister
[0:06 - 0:33]

The scene begins with a wide area shot of the green, rolling hills.

In the background, two people slowly approach each other.

The camera alternates between these two characters. A young (~ 25) woman with piercing green eyes and wild, shoulder longer hair
and an older man with deep brown eyes and short, darker hair who, despite bearing the signs of stress in his face and
the faint gray strands of hair near his sideburns, has a youthful glow about him.

[0:34 - 0:39]

The camera shift to her backyard. She is sitting in a chair, her sight glaring into the distance.

[0:40 - 0:45]

Shift to him. He is on a hike. Flowers blossom in the background and all around him.
He stops for a moment, his eyes staring off into the distance, meaningfully.

[0:46 - 0:59]

Closeups of their faces are shown, side by side.
The viewer can spot the pain and frustration in their faces, yet also
a faint, strong glimmer of hope.

[1:00 - 1:27]

Flashbacks to an earlier time, when the two of them were still together.
Of the two of them watching the sky in amazement. When they held hands and softly touched
each other's lips.
When they were one with nature and all its creations ... and one with each other.

[1:28 - 1:34]

The camera fades back to her backyard, but she is gone.

[1:35 - 1:39]

Likewise, he vanished from his parcel of nature.

[1:40 - 1:53]

The waters that separate both of them from each other are shown.
Their faces are slowly brought into focus.
They stare at each other from a distance. Glares of love and desire are being exchanged.

[1:54 - 2:19]

Images of their painful pasts are being projected. Of the things that nearly destroyed them
but, in the end, made them stronger. In a sense, their pasts prepared them for each other.

It is implied that the past no longer matters. That nothing compares to the pain of not being together.

[2:20 - 2:46]

Their worlds merge. Both her backyard and his wilderness slowly come into focus and
blur into one.

[2:47 - 2:59]

The merging continues, revealing one perfect, solemn image.

[3:00 - 3:05]

The waters that once separated them vanish.

[3:06 - 3:15]

Throwback to the first scene. Both of them have now made their
way towards each other. They embrace and kiss, slowly yet passionately.

1 Jan 2020, 20:18
Shelmo Porter
1. I was never made aware that you were trying to prolong your trip, because you were too caught up in the kids having messed with your car (understandably).

2. I had set an alarm for 12:30 so I could wake you. I was in a dead sleep when you woke me up, and anything you think you heard in my tone was probably not whatever you thought it was. I was tired, confused, and just wanting to get back to sleep. You didn't give me a second to wake up properly before kissing me goodbye and such, and I asked if you were leaving already because for some reason I'd thought you weren't leaving until 1 am. A simple miscommunication.

3. See 5.

4. I hope you DO get the job, whichever one you want most. I've never implied that I didn't think you should or could, so I don't know why this is in here.

5. My own family often takes it upon themselves to meddle in my emotional and romantic life. My aunt thinks I am cruel and heartless, and that I'll never truly love anyone because I hate myself too much to let anyone in. My father doesn't think I'll find real love because I was raised by my mother and he thinks my mother is both crazy and a whore. My mental health is always under speculation because I've never recovered from growing up on psychotropic drugs that I never needed.
I don't feel like I'm worthy of love, and I don't feel like I am adjusted as a person, because nobody in my life who should be on my side IS on my side. Not my mother or father(s), aunts or uncles, brothers, sisters, cousins, childhood friends....nobody but you, apparently. A man from Germany who lashes out at me instead of trying to understand why I'm having a breakdown, and writes crude things about me in a journal (which I am then subjected to reading), and yet insists that he loves me. I can't believe that I'm loved. I don't know how to respond to being loved. I don't know what it is or what to do with it, so I need all the patience I can get.
I told my dad it wasn't serious because he kept hounding me about you and I didn't know what else to tell him. "Hi, yeah, this is the guy I was dating on Halloween but then we broke up because I had a mental breakdown and now he's here trying to win me back over"? Is that what I should have told him? This whole situation feels like it just keeps getting crazier, to me, and I'm watching myself fuck up over and over again but I don't know what else to do with myself.
You aren't a fling. I never wanted you to be a fling. If that's what you feel like, I'm sorry. I don't know how to fix that.

6. See 5.

7. I will stop. It was merely my way of trying to keep my boundaries in place, which didn't even work because we still ended up having (mutually consensual) sex literally the night before you left. I have no excuse for that other than that we're both humans and our bodies have needs. Shit happens. I don't know what to do about that and I'm frankly getting too tired to try figuring it out any further. It just...happened.

8. The last few days have been me trying to get comfortable with you again without putting too much pressure on us. I want us both to be happy. But I agree, it does seem forced. I worry that the only way to fix this would be for us both to just turn our backs on each other and get on with our lives, but I know you'll never want to do that. I'm at a loss. I don't know what to do either.
I'm sorry.
1 Jan 2020, 20:04
Mark Bauermeister
Since you couldn't understand me entirely earlier, here's what I said in a (very large) nutshell.

1. I tried prolonging the trip. Monday afternoon, while Izzy and Bella toyed with my car, I was making some calls to my boss and to American Airlines, hoping ... bartering ... that I may postpone my return flight by a couple of days.
I wouldn't do this for just about any person. Especially not a person I consider unworthy of my love and attention.

2. I would've loved to stay until 1 AM this morning, but American wouldn't allow me to check-in online, so I had to rush things further. Even then I only got there in the nick of time, as evidenced by the fact I didn't even have time to properly check on my belongings prior to boarding.

3. Any time you tell me you're "unlovable", it feels like a deep stab. Like what you're actually insinuating is that I don't love you or, conversely, since you deem yourself "unlovable" that I don't deserve any love from you either.

4. I'm trying really hard to get a job stateside (I have already applied for one frontend designer job at Waitr in Baton Rouge this morning). I'm doing it with or without you, although I can't deny I'd prefer the former.

5. Amy told me I was dumb and should have more self-respect. That you're a hopeless case and I'm just wasting my time being around you. That I'm somebody who loves you, does his best to take care of you and would go through hell for you, yet you don't appreciate it.

While it was undeniably "drunk talk", she does have a point. I'm just really sick of the flip-flopping, having my motives questioned and, occasionally, feeling like you're just holding out for something better.

6. When your dad left, he looked at me almost pitiful, and the question "Will I meet you again?" sent a shockwave through my spine.

That question only hours after I returned from the wood pile and couldn't help but overhear a conversation wherein you told your dad it was "nothing serious".

I know we aren't a couple, but I told you before I don't want to be a fling either.

7. You don't need to verbally remind me we aren't a couple. I remind myself. Every night I go to bed without you. Every morning I don't wake up next to you. And the nightmares in-between are a constant reminder, too.

8. I'm just really anxious that the past few days were merely an effort to try to make me happy (while ignoring your own happiness) and that you're going to cut me out for good once I'm just a speckle in the distance.

My soul is old; perhaps older than even I myself am capable of comprehending. I've stood strong through numerous attacks of all kinds. Nothing has conquered me to this day, and nothing will, for I am meant to be free. My love is one not born of this world, but one meant to encapsulate and cherish all of humanity unconditionally. Like the mountains, I stand rigid and unafraid in the face of eternity. I don't need to be full of life because I am a building block OF life. I am hope. I am fear. I am made of the very stuff that seeks even now to destroy me.

9 Dec 2019, 13:47
Mark Bauermeister
He is still befuddled as to why she thinks she isn't good enough for him.
If it hadn't been for her, he would've never forgotten about the drama of the past two years. He would've never found his voice. Never figured out what he wanted in life. He would've never sought therapeutic help. He would've never been able to admit that he isn't flawless. He certainly would've never put his own flaws under the microscope. He would've never gotten that new outlook on things.
He's selfish too, in a way. Because it's not just love alone that ties him to her, but also the potential of what she'll be able to do to him. How else she will help him discover previously concealed parts of himself. Likewise, he looks forward to seeing her unlock her full potential, no matter how long things may take.

He doesn't want to stress her out or make her feel pressured. This will, most likely, be the final message of its kind for a while. He will see her soon enough, in person. He just wants her to feel at ease. He wants to finally feel at ease again himself. He wants to make sure she's alright.
He wants her to know he's taking better care of himself again.

https://youtu.be/SdhAfMor9BM
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SdhAfMor9BM
9 Dec 2019, 13:30
Mark Bauermeister
Selfishness and cowardice are an inherent human trait. We all have it in us. It's good when we can admit as much.

Even fickleness isn't a deal breaker. It's not an insult to call somebody fickle. Not a bad trait to be fickle. Fickleness is merely a personal boundary. An indicator that, sometimes, the other party needs to help slow things down until such time the person can feel more comfortable.
He knows this. Recognizes this. Acknowledge her boundaries and what she is going through. He will help her slow things down. He initially felt overwhelmed by how quickly things were going, too. Back then he accepted his fate, maybe he shouldn't have. Maybe he should've been stubborn. Told her he wanted that relationship, but not put all of that stress on either party. Not that soon, not in such a large dosage. He can't deny he wants the future she painted for him, but he is painfully aware that the present is still out there and needs to be full enjoyed and explored first. She is enough for him. He doesn't need a giant property. He doesn't need children or to come up with names for children that aren't even born. He doesn't need to think about marriage. All he needs is to be with her, regardless of the label either party wants to apply to it. All he wants is her.
8 Dec 2019, 18:37
Shelmo Porter
He doesn't need to.
I'm terrified that he's going to tear himself apart before he gets here.
I've been beating myself up since that day in November, because I know this is all me. It's not a matter of his intrinsic value, or his worth. It's a matter of me not knowing how to just slow tf down and accept a good thing for what it is.

I hope he gets some rest, warms up, and actually EATS something when he wakes up. If he falls ill trying to prove himself to me, I'll never be able to forgive myself.

Time for me to sleep for the first time since Monday. Christmas decorating can wait. I've had enough.
8 Dec 2019, 18:30
Mark Bauermeister
He's not trying to make it public. Only she has the link to his journal. He's not trying to come off like a caricature, nor is he fishing for sympathies. It's his way of trying to make her understand just how much he thinks she's worth it. Self-sacrifice. He's willing to do it. Willing to go through all of this, to become the man she can love and who is worth it. He'd gladly keep going, but now he has to consider the consequences of his actions. He isn't scared, just considerate. He lost the ability to be scared or to produce any tears a while ago. Deep inside he knows things will be alright, even if they're going to be complicated. He'll make her understand the full spectrum of his feelings somehow, without breaking her. He knows text is easier than finding his own voice, but he'll do the latter if he has to. He doesn't want to stress her out. Is pained to know that she is miserable, too. Even though he says and feels like he is no longer scared, he still feels a covert panic. He's working on it.
8 Dec 2019, 18:25
Shelmo Porter
How do I tell him I'm getting sick? And even worse, how do I tell him that he's making it worse? Every day, every few hours, I find myself opening his journal in a desperate bid to understand what he's going through, and what he's been through.
He slept on a bench last night. A fucking wooden bench, and I'm pissed. He's disregarding his own health and safety, but why?
A thought hits me sideways, full of venom, and sends my mind reeling.
The drama. The emotion. He's compiling his thoughts so I can read it like I've subscribed to some sort of psychiatric magazine, in the hopes that those words will reach me. Why go to all these extra steps? Why not just tell me directly? For someone who thinks I treat him like he's a caricature, he's certainly making it awfully hard not to at this point. Taking pictures of his food and of the bench, like he's showing off his misery.

I'm miserable too. He's not the only one suffering, so why is he the only one making a show of himself? Not every struggle needs to be public. Not every heart pain needs to become a billboard.
I love him, but I can't stand to see him like this. It's getting to the point that if he can't snap out of it, I won't want to see him ever again. Christmas is starting to feel like the beginning of the end, at least to me.

Maybe if I can write back to him, without writing TO him, he'll see. He needs to stop treating himself so unkindly, and realize that if he keeps going down this road he is going to end up crawling to me across my driveway in a pool of his own tears. I'll never forgive myself for this. How can I? I've taken something beautiful and stepped on it, for no reason other than my fear of letting it keep being beautiful.
I am selfish, and I am cowardly, and he deserves better.
How can I explain that I just don't feel like I'm good enough?

5 Dec 2019, 16:35
Mark Bauermeister
I know you don't want to hear it, but since you asked me once in the past... Here's why my belly button looks like Frankenstein's Monster.

When I was 19 (pushing 20), I was with an older woman (she was 28 then). We both went to the same Community College and spent a lot of time together.

Our relationship was exactly what you described your exes were like. I still adored her (not like I adore you. More like a dog adoring its master. I never questioned or criticized her nor her obvious abuse, which should've been the healthy thing to do).

Still. One day things went sour. She vanished for a weekend, without notice. Even her best friend didn't know her whereabouts. When she came back, I realized I wanted to find closure and not deal with her anymore.

That's when I met her OTHER BF. Not only was she dating two people at the same time, behind each other's backs, the other guy didn't take too kindly to me running up to the person he believed to be dating exclusively. He grabbed the next available object, which was a very sharp screwdriver.

The rest is ER history.

It took me a long time to get over that sort of betrayal, yet eventually (after more than half a decade) I just took the step. Because I knew people would catch me if/when I slip. I stopped running. Running from myself. Running from others. Running from the consequences of my own actions. I didn't regret it. I don't even regret the other drama that followed in its wake.

Without all that drama, I would've never met you.
Despite that emotional rollercoaster, I still don't regret meeting you (I do regret not getting to spend more time with you. And I regret that you weren't getting to know me better).
Nor am I drawing parallels between you and the people in my past.
There was a time I felt almost inclined to do so (and again this morning), but I quickly realized it wasn't fair to draw those parallels. Not to you, not to myself.

The house is legally theirs, but the belongings inside of it are yours. LEGALLY, they cannot just throw anything they want away without your express permission, and you CAN sue them for missing or damaged items.
25 Nov 2019, 18:09
Shelmo Porter
And seriously. Invest in either a storage shed or a storage unit elsewhere for things that are terribly important (ie anything collectible that you plan on displaying or selling)

Mark Bauermeister
Made it!

Sorry for the less than perfect end to that evening. I'll make it up to you, and I'll see to it that I'll be healthy again in the morning.

Furthermore, sorry I burdened you with more kitchen utensils.

You're right. Amy's kitchen is already full enough as it is.

There are three reasons I do stuff like that.

1. I hate throwing away perfectly good items.

2. That provider instinct. Me wanting to make sure you have everything you need.

3. Some sort of mislead romantic attachment to "firsts" (hell. I still have that receipt from our first time at Freddy's in my wallet).

That's something I need to work on. There will be so many more firsts, our own household would look like a garbage pile if I kept going like this.

I still got the plates. Either I'll throw them out in the morning or ... if you know a place, we can smash them together. For good luck.

18 Nov 2019, 20:01
Shelmo Porter
How you show love isn't a problem to me. I'm a simple woman, and grand gestures make me feel kind of like a spotlight is on me, but I can get over that. It's really just more of the things that occupy your mind and how you do certain things that gets to me.

I'm emotional, and I'm passionate in the things I love AND in the things I hate or stand against.
Racism, homophobia and hypersexual jokes aren't a joking matter to me. I don't find them funny, whether the joke was made seriously or not. The biggest lynchpin of my personality is that I love EVERYBODY honestly and openly, regardless of who or what they are, where they're from, who they love.... I don't approve of baseless hatred, or people who try to make light of that hatred through shitty half-baked humor.

You drive recklessly. I don't ever feel safe when I go somewhere with you because you don't pay attention to your surroundings and you don't take measures to keep your passengers safe (aside from you literally yelling at me last night to put my seatbelt on, which was not necessary). You don't HAVE to pass every car in front of you. You don't HAVE to ride people's ass when they ARE in front of you going the speed limit. You don't have to go 80 in a 55. You need to be more mindful of what lanes you're in and stay off the damn shoulder. I've been driving for a year and I feel more secure behind my own wheel than I do behind yours- and I grew up being chauffeured around everywhere because my parents were better off. I'm USED to trusting other people's driving.

You care too much about Lauren Ann and what her friends are up to. And while I can understand that because you were done really REALLY wrong by them, and I support you and will defend you to the ends of the earth against them.....it's the fact that you feel a need to make a grand sweeping public statement calling everyone out. Deal with your problems yourself. Don't call attention to yourself on facebook because
1. Nobody gives a fuck
2. PSA announcements and blog posting just make you look desperate for an audience to whine to.
Just keep blocking them all, make your posts more private and cut off their fuel until they disappear. They WILL disappear.

You're too sexual. Your fantasies are too much and too frequent and it makes me feel very objectified as a woman and as a partner. Last night, I was trying to tell the kids a bedtime story so I could go asleep, and you were in my inbox talking about how you want me to fuck you in a mask and asking me to say "good boy" into the microphone for you.
1. The good boy thing is getting excessive. It almost feels like you're getting off to a mommy figure, and i don't feel as confortable with it anymore.
2. Yes. I am your girlfriend. You came here to see me. But we don't have to have sex or do sexual things at every single opportunity we get. I can't do it. I'm tired, and overworked, and my body is too exhausted to keep up with your constant urges.

It's true. The Celts (who we now know are actually a conglomerate of Germanic, Breton, Slavic and Scandinavian peoples who settled Ireland waaaaaaay way back forever ago) are one of the earliest recorded societies in which women were treated as equal to men. Women could own property, fight in battles in the summer season like the men, and sail. Breton law protected them and their children, and even allowed for divorce before the Protestant reformation.

This mixture should be 50% chopped oysters, 25% cheese, 25% spinach. If you can find clean oyster shells spoon a little in each one. If not buy a package of puff pastry shells and fill them with the mixture.

Bake about 12 minutes at 350.

Itâ€™s delicious. Sometimes I sprinkle a little crushed bacon on top before baking.

Anything else should be done with fresh oysters, especially in Louisiana"

25 Aug 2019, 17:51
Mark Bauermeister
Oh. After she was done with me, I definitely became a recluse for a bit.

It's just before I met her, I was a massive douche. Only cared about myself and personal gain.

Then I met her, saw her (fake) caring for others, and eventually adopted that same care in earnest.

Started with a homeless veteran we spotted on the street. Guy wanted to take a greyhound back to Chicago and was looking for money. She talked to him first then was suddenly gone for a moment only to reappear with a huge plastic bag full of quarters.

When I saw that, I grabbed my wallet and gave the guy ten bucks. Admittedly, partly to posture to her. That being said, it felt great to help a man in need.
